newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX gasoline ends lower on oversupply concerns.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX gasoline ends lower on oversupply concerns.

text.p: NYMEX gasoline prices ended sharply lower Thursday as talk of imports from Europe arriving on top of ample U.S. stocks fueled concerns of oversupply, traders said.
"It's a combination of imports when we have ample supply, and the gasoline season being now over," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil.
October gasoline settled down 1.74 cent at 61.32 cents a gallon after falling as low as 60.40 cents during the day. Support was pegged at 60.40 and after that at $59.70.
"Sell stops were triggered at around 61.25," said a trader explaining gasoline's drop Thursday to 60.40.
Gasoline demand traditionally peaks during the summer, but inventory draws this summer were considered lackluster by traders.
Meanwhile, shipping sources have noticed a sharp increase in charters for gasoline shipments from Europe to the United States in September.
October crude oil settled off 35 cents to $23.54 a barrel and October heating oil settled 1.10 cent lower to 66.77 cents a gallon on profit-taking.

Crude and heating oil rallied strongly Wednesday after inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute showed a much smaller-than-expected build in heating oil stocks. Heating oil stocks are at historical lows as winter approaches.
Traders said the demand for heating oil and the demand for crude to produce it contained Thursday's selling in both.

The strength of crude prices, energized recently by U.S.- Iraqi tensions, has deteriorated the gasoline-to-crude crack spread. The gasoline crack closed at $2.21 a barrel, the lowest level since mid-October of 1994.

The weaker fundamentals in gasoline has made it a laggard on the NYMEX for months, though traders said gasoline prices could go higher during the winter as refiners produce less gasoline in favor of heating oil.

"There has been a great deal of pressure on gasoline for some time, but things will change later in the season, and then one can make a strong case for it," said Thomas Blakeslee of Cargill Investor Services.
Traders said market forces are also creating a disincentive for refiners to make gasoline due to the deteriorating premium of gasoline over crude oil, which hurts profitability.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk, 212-859-1761
